title: High-Contrast Transitional Serif
content:
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/48413419@N00/15497085298/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414163708/https:/www.flickr.com/photos/48413419@N00/15497085298/ "https://www.flickr.com/photos/48413419@N00/15497085298/")  
From the cover of a book published in 1975.  
What is it?

hhp
author: hrant

comments.content:
The curved serifs do add a nice touch—definitely an artifact of the phototypesetting process, and one sadly not easily replicated via type on a curve these days.

Looks an awful lot like Modern No. 20, originally released by Stephenson Blake in 1905. Ed Benguiat's digital version came out in 1990:

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/modern-no-20/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414163708/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/modern-no-20/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/modern-no-20/")

That's probably it, presuming a poor digitization.  
Thanks!

hhp
